awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Establishing and Propagating a Model for Evaluating the Long Term Impact of Pre-College Computing Activities
awd_abstract_narration:
There is a critical need to increase the number of skilled technology workers within the United States, with computing skills becoming increasingly important as the nation moves further into the 21st century. This need is fueled by the realization that the number of tech workers needed to maintain political and economic security far outweighs the current workers available now or in the immediate future. To increase interest, commercial, governmental, and not-for-profit educational groups have sponsored numerous initiatives aimed to bring computing to more students, recently with a K-12 emphasis. This project seeks to determine the long-term impact of these activities as a mechanism for growing the skilled technology workforce within the United States.  
 
The goal of this project is to create the resources and tools necessary for identifying best practices for identifying the long term impact of these pre-college computing activities on participants, including analyses of data based on gender and ethnicity. The project's scope will include two phases: 1) the identification, review, and analysis of past and current pre-college computing activities and their impact on participants to determine the major influencing variables and 2) the creation and implementation of a formal process for collecting data related to pre-college computing activities, including major influencing variables, necessary for educational researchers to be able to evaluate and analyze the long-term impact of these activities. Two significant outputs from this project are the creation of instruments available for measuring the long-term effects of pre-college computing efforts; and measurement results from using these instruments to evaluate the effects of current and past pre-college computing efforts.

por.por_cntn:
The main goals of the first phase of the project were centered around more awareness and better presentation and aggregation of data about the participants, outcomes, and nature of computing activities available to students prior to college. In the first part of the project, we created a place where anyone can go to find out about pre-college computing activities by the creation of the K-12 CS Education Research Resource Center that was launched in 2018. Since then we have had over 38,000 unique visitors to the site, showing a significant need among the community. If an educator or researcher would like to know about certain activities for certain age groups or if they wanted to know about the results of using certain activities for certain age groups, the resources are now available and users are able to easily find related research.  

With the data manually curated from over 1,000 articles centered on K-12 CS education research, we published a multitude of articles that examine the evidence across them as well as their equity-focus and where the research gaps are. Our efforts are in support of creating a strong foundation for evidence that can drive promising practices for decision-makers and practitioners. We also created a set of CS-specific evaluation instruments for free and general usage for any researcher to adopt and adapt as needed. Finally, we created a set of research guides with specific information for CS education researchers, so that they can receive quick tips and guidance on conducting K-12 CS education research.

The project conducted two major events in the form of workshops that brought together teachers, researchers, and other education professionals to discuss issues facing the state of the art of computing education research in K-12 spaces. The first workshop, held in conjunction with the ICER 2019 conference, brought computing education researchers together to look at issues of research and evaluation of computing education across the entire K-16 spectrum with subgroups focused on the various grade bands' unique challenges and opportunities. The second, held in conjunction with the CSTA 2022 conference, was focused on bringing K-8 teachers and researchers together to focus on proposing solutions to the research to practice gap and to empower classroom teachers to realize that they can have a voice in the work that is going on in this area.

In addition, the project presented the resource center and results of data analysis of the information in the research center in numerous panels, webinars and presentations at various venues including national and international conferences, research groups, and other organizational meetings. The project has been advertised as a resource for authors at major computing education conferences.  

Lastly and significantly, the new non-profit organization CSEdResearch.org was formed based on the work conducted from this NSF funded project. This is providing a critical platform for building the K-12 CS education research community as well as for disseminating and sharing information with other researchers and practitioners.

 


Last Modified: 12/22/2022
Modified by: Monica M Mcgill
